• Was originally just a pick about a new, as-yet-unannounced iOS 15 feature, but the hosts suspected that was another reuse.
  • In retrospect, this was a tricky pick to grade because how would we know the day after the event? Federico provides some insider information indicating that the setting does exist, but can it be said to have "come true", as the rule states, without proof? The meaning of truth itself is debated, perhaps a philosophical high point for the Rickies. The point is ultimately granted, with the understanding that in the future, the rules will be amended to clarify that picks must be publicly verifiable to earn points.

Myke believed that a 10% margin on either side is too wide to be risky and also that the AirPower one is just a better risky pick with less math. It's pointed out that Qi 2 is basically just standardized MagSafe as well, but it's still allowed as they'll have to be specific about Qi 2 to count it. Stephen still thinks it lacks passion. Later, Federico sprinkled some passion on it after all by adding a charging wattage increase after all.

picks.text: Apple announces a new standalone "Siri app" based on a new LLM that will...
picks.full-pick-text: Apple announces a new standalone "Siri app" based on a new LLM that will be multilingual and support multiple languages at the same time, support multiple modalities â€“ e.g. text input, voice input, and image attachments in the same conversation, and display content from third-party apps inline based on a new developer framework.
picks.notes:
• "Be multilingual and support multiple languages at the same time."
  • "Support multiple modalities â€“ e.g. text input, voice input, or image attachments in the same conversation."
  • "Display content from third-party apps inline based on a new developer framework."
  • If the overall pick about a "Siri app" is wrong, all the details will be counted as wrong as well. But that won't be a problem because Federico thinks that this approach is "so obvious".

picks.text: Apple introduces a new smart home product that features a screen...
picks.full-pick-text: Apple introduces a new smart home product that features a screen. It will be in the HomePod line of products, it will feature eye/hand tracking as a way to control the interface without needing to touch the screen, and it will feature support for third party apps to run on the device.
picks.notes:
• "It will be in the HomePod line of products."
  • "It will feature eye or hand tracking as a way to control the interface without needing to touch the screen."
  • "And it will feature support for third party apps to run on the device."
  • Apps may not necessarily come from a dedicated App Store, it may be more like CarPlay or some form of mirroring. Just widgets or Live Activities will not count, there has to be UI that you interact with.

picks.text: Apple opens up AFM (Apple Foundation Model) to developers
picks.full-pick-text: Apple opens up AFM (Apple Foundation Model) to developers. It's a 3B parameter version only that runs on device. It's designed in a way that only specific "endpoints" can be used with a native API, like summarization or writing or prioritizing content. Apple shows off examples of how they're using the same tech in its own system apps.
picks.notes:
• "It's a 3B parameter version only that runs on device."
  • "It's designed in a way that only specific "endpoints" can be used with a native API, like summarization or writing or prioritizing content." (In other words, developers won't be able to prompt the API with arbitrary text, they only have access to particular tasks like summarization.)
  • "Apple shows off examples of how they're using the same tech in its own system apps."

There is a build-to-order option that exceeds the unified memory available on the Mac Studio, which currently tops out at 512 GB.

• "The starting price remains at $6,999."
